information: The United States recently implemented a general 10% tariff on imports from most trading partners. Concurrently, the administration has pursued other trade actions, including imposing a 25% tariff on imported automobiles and certain auto parts, and increasing tariffs on Chinese goods to over 100% in response to retaliatory measures. Additionally, new tariffs ranging from 41% to over 3,500% have been announced on solar imports from several Southeast Asian countries, pending a final decision in June 2025.

forecast.no_outcome_scenario: The US–Israel FTA remains in force with “IL” special rates largely Free; no country-specific 17% line is added to the HTS for Israel. Any new US tariff programs (e.g., broad baseline tariffs, sectoral measures, AD/CVD cases) either exclude Israel, or are implemented via Chapter 99 in ways that do not present as a “+17% for Israel” in the applicable subheadings by June 1.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: The administration implements a country-specific, across-the-board “reciprocal” tariff program that assigns Israel a 17% additional duty (e.g., tied to Israel’s 17% VAT) and encodes it in the HTS—likely via Chapter 99—with language that clearly displays “+ 17% for Israel” when the HTS is queried on or after June 1, 2025. Alternatively, ILFTA preferences are suspended and a special Israel rate of 17% is explicitly added to applicable subheadings (even if listed as suspended).
forecast.rationale: Baseline: Under the US–Israel FTA, the HTS typically lists “IL” with Free for most lines. There is no standing US policy that sets a uniform, country-specific 17% tariff on Israel. HTS country-specific adders (like the China Section 301 duties) usually appear as Chapter 99 additional duties, not as a replacement line item of “+17% for Israel” in standard subheadings. Politically and legally, imposing a targeted across-the-board tariff on Israel by June 1 would be unusual given the alliance, FTA obligations, and WTO constraints; suspending ILFTA or creating a bespoke 17% rate would be a significant, visible departure. Timing: With ~5 weeks left, implementing, proclaiming, encoding, and publishing a country-specific 17% for Israel that is visible on hts.usitc.gov by June 1 is a tight window. Research assistant input: They report a general 10% tariff and other trade actions. Even if accurate, these are not Israel-specific and would more likely be reflected as general or Chapter 99 measures rather than as a dedicated “Israel 17%” line in the HTS. The 17% figure plausibly maps to a “reciprocal” tariff pegged to Israel’s 17% VAT—an idea floated in policy circles—but enacting that rapidly, and in a way that the HTS shows as “+17% for Israel,” remains unlikely. Why not higher: Significant institutional, legal, and political hurdles; unusual to single out Israel; HTS convention typically uses Chapter 99 adders, and AD/CVD actions do not change the base HTS country rate display. Why not lower: A small chance exists that a sweeping reciprocal-tariff program rolls out quickly with per-country adders, including Israel at 17%, and that USITC publishes a visible HTS entry (even if marked suspended) by June 1. What would move me up: - An official White House/USTR announcement of a reciprocal tariff regime assigning 17% to Israel. - A presidential proclamation or USITC notice adding Chapter 99 provisions explicitly stating an additional 17% duty on “products of Israel,” with HTS website previews showing the text. - Notice of ILFTA suspension with specific 17% rates. What would move me down: - Signals that any baseline tariff excludes FTA partners (including Israel). - USITC/CBP guidance indicating no country-specific HTS lines for Israel will be posted before June 1.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will the US government's harmonized tarifff schedule list the tariff on Israel as 17% on June 1, 2025?

Question background:
Times of Israel: [Israeli exports to US will take annual $2.3B hit under tariffs, industrial org warns](https://www.timesofisrael.com/israeli-exports-to-us-will-take-2-3-billion-hit-under-tariffs-industrialist-org-warns/)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if the duty provided in the applicable subheading is + 17% for Israel at the American government's [harmonized tariff schedule](https://hts.usitc.gov/search?query=israel) when accessed by Metaculus on or after June 1, 2025.

Whether the provision is listed as suspended will not affect resolution.


Your research assistant's report says:
The United States recently implemented a general 10% tariff on imports from most trading partners. Concurrently, the administration has pursued other trade actions, including imposing a 25% tariff on imported automobiles and certain auto parts, and increasing tariffs on Chinese goods to over 100% in response to retaliatory measures. Additionally, new tariffs ranging from 41% to over 3,500% have been announced on solar imports from several Southeast Asian countries, pending a final decision in June 2025.

Today is 2025-04-24.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
